intro: Tetragonotheca texana, commonly known as the Texas four-angle dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as sandy soils and rocky areas. Its leaves are opposite, lance-shaped, and often have a rough texture. The flower heads are yellow and bloom in the spring, producing small, wind-dispersed seeds.
